title: 105_hr2492
content: The "Career Transition Assistance Act of 1997" is cited as the short title. It excludes severance payments from income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Career Transition Assistance Act of 1997 excludes qualified severance payments from an individual's gross income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The exclusion amount is limited to $15,000 for each separation from employment, with certain conditions on when the payment is received. The term 'qualified severance payment' refers to a payment made by an employer to an individual upon separation from employment due to a workforce reduction. This payment is excluded from gross income under the Career Transition Assistance Act of 1997. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996. A new section is added for retraining expenses for older long-time employees who are laid off. The tax code allows for a credit against the tax imposed for eligible individuals equal to qualified job training expenses paid during the taxable year, with a maximum credit of $2,000. This credit is subject to a limitation based on adjusted gross income. The tax code allows for a credit against the tax imposed for eligible individuals equal to qualified job training expenses paid during the taxable year, with a maximum credit of $2,000. The credit is subject to a limitation based on adjusted gross income, with specific applicable dollar amounts for different filing statuses. Any determined amount not a multiple of $10 is rounded to the next lowest $10. The tax code provides a credit for eligible individuals for qualified job training expenses paid during the taxable year, with a maximum credit of $2,000. The credit is subject to income limitations based on filing status, with specific dollar amounts for each status. Eligible individuals must have separated from employment due to a workforce reduction and be at least 50 years old. The tax code offers a credit for qualified job training expenses up to $2,000 for eligible individuals who have been employed full-time for 20 years or more and are at least 50 years old. Qualified expenses include tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment for education or training programs. The tax code provides a credit for job training expenses for eligible individuals, covering tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, meals, and lodging while attending an eligible educational institution or training program. Eligible educational institutions include institutions of higher education or vocational schools. The term 'institution of higher education' refers to institutions described in the Higher Education Act of 1965, while 'vocational school' means an area vocational education school as defined in the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Applied Technology Education Act. 'Applicable training program' includes programs defined in the Job Training Partnership Act. Technical amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996.
